SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name ...........................................
Address ...........................................
Birthplace ..........................................

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906 ........................

Where did you set up housekeeping? 1906 on Homestead near Watson, Sask.

Where had you been living before that? Loch Morar, Man (Now Inwood)

For how many people did you prepare meals? Just Two, self and Husband

How far was it to your nearest store? 18 Miles

How often could a visit be made to the store? Summer 2 weeks, Winter 2 Mos

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Not much, Flour, Tea, Rice, Oatmeal, Syrup, salt, Cornstarch, Sugar.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Ogilvies or Local brand milled at Watson, Sask. Al Gregory, Mill

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 Lbs

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50

How much did you use graham flour? Very Little

Whole wheat flour? Very Little

Was flour milled locally? Yes How far away? 18 Miles What year? 1906

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 45¢

What other grain products did you use? Wheat, ground by self

Cornmeal? No Whole Wheat? No Farina? No

Other? Ground Wheat

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes

How did you grind it? Generally in Coffee mill
1906. Neal, Mrs. Eric
Lone, Alta.

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

Sometimes 100 lb bag

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 20 Lbs Bulk, no cotton bag then

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 5¢ lb

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb can, gallon

At what price? 90¢

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

Had a cow On Homestead

Butter? Made our own

Eggs? Had chickens

What was the price of butter? 15¢ lb

Of eggs? 6 to 8¢ doz

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, with lard

How? Wrap individually in paper, and pack in box, and keep in cellar

Did you make butter? Yes

Cheese? Yes

What kind of cheese? Just Dutch cheese

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Raised and killed pig

For winter, pickled or cured some for summer

How did you get fresh meat? Shot deer in winter (plentiful), Rabbits

Lots of ducks in summer and fall. (Some people main diet was rabbits)

How often did you get fresh meat? Regular as above

How did you preserve meat? Pickled pork in brine or smoked

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes

What kinds? Ducks, Geese, Deer

For how long? Three years

What part did fish play in the family diet? None here; nearest fish in lakes 50 miles away

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Kinds? Some canned salmon, but seldom, finances limited

and relied mostly on what we raised
2. **Some Things I Need**

   - In what quantity did you buy milk last month? 20 lbs., half-gallon, no cotton bag.
   - What was the price for a ten pound sack of whole wheat? $1.50.
   - What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Domino.
   - What size of tin or syrup did you usually buy? 20 lb. gallon.
   - At what price? $0.96.

3. **Dairy Products**

   - How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?
     - Had a cow on homestead.
     - Bought from neighbors.
     - Bought from store.
   - What was the price of butter? 15¢/lb. or 6¢/dozen.
   - Did you make butter? Yes.
   - Did you make cheese? Yes.
   - What kind of cheese? Cheddar.

4. **Meat and Fish**

   - What was your meat supply in the early years?
     - Raised and killed on farm.
     - Purchased at market.
     - Purchased at store.
   - How did you get fresh meat?
     - Shot deer in winter (plentiful).
     - Lots of ducks in summer and fall (some alone, some in flocks).
     - Purchased at store.
   - How often did you eat fresh meat?
     - Twice a week.
     - Once a week.
     - Rarely.
   - How did you procure meat?
     - Plucked, cooked, and eaten.
     - Purchased at store.
   - Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? No.
   - If so, what year was it organized? 1910.
   - Did you use family? Yes.
   - Did you use friends? Yes.
   - For how long? Three years.
   - What part did fish play in the family diet? None, very little.
   - Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned.
   - How? Canned salmon, but seldom.
   - And filled mostly on what we raised.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? mostly Bulk At what price? 3 lbs $1.00
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Mostly beans
Price? 20 cents lb What other beverages were used? milk

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 25¢/bus Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes
If not, where from? Raised our own or from neighbor, cost nil.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1906 Cabbages 1906 Carrots 1906 Onions 1906
Turnips 1906 Beets 1906

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? usually 25 lbs (5¢/lb)

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Box
What weight? 10 lbs How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes
What was the price of prunes? 9¢/lb

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?
Some apples, Raisens, Currants, couldn't afford, relied on wild fruit which was preserved for winter

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? .............
peas? Yes corn? Yes beans? Yes Saskatoons? No
other foods? ..................................................................

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? Only wild fruit in period 1906-10, in sealers or made jam.
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1925
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1925

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning Yes
mostly fowl, beef, fruit

To what extent? Not to any great extent as all are available fresh in most towns and villages

Did you make your own vinegar? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ........................................... Dug well, only 12 feet deep.

How far was this water from your home? ........................................... 40 feet.

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) ........................................... pail, and pulled out of well by pail on a rope.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We left homestead in 1909, most people have deep wells now with pump and power, and in many cases farms homes have water system in.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ................. wood ashes

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes ........... wood ashes? No ...........

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Brown Soap

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Poplar wood

Where did you get your fuel? On and near homestead

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. In wooded areas many people still burn wood, with some coal in winter for heating. Generally speaking, coal is used most both in town and farm homes since 1910. Today many use oil for heating, also natural gas in areas where there is a supply. The more modern homes use electricity especially for cooking and this use is increasing as power lines are extended in the rural areas.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No

By whom was your first cook stove made? Mrs. McCrary

What year was it purchased? 1905 Price? Second hand?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) ..........

Had some of old type iron pots, some tin

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Some wooden bowls, some earthenware

When did you first see enamel ware? Think about 1900

Aluminum? 1910 nearly all tin or Iron before these dates
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers associated with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Most food was in the bulk, and was put into paper bags and if necessary wrapped them in strong brown wrapping paper and tied with parcel string. The fancy containers and cans started to come in about 1910.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Born in Manitoba 1886 my early life spent 60 miles north east of Winnipeg in ranching country. As I remember breakfast did not vary much. Porridge, fried potatoes, meat, Bread & Butter Milk, Tea, or Coffee. Dinner beef, pork fish or wild game, rice or tapioca pudding, Bread & Butter, Vegetable Syrup, Milk, Tea, Coffee. Supper, Bread & butter, Syrup, Jam sometimes a cake, not often. Plain wholesome food and lots of it. This was so in the 80s and 90s. Dad and Mother and seven kids.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

I ate my first Xmas dinner in Manitoba and if I remember right we had either Beef, Turkey, Chicken, Plum pudding and all the trimmings. My dad and Mother and one sister. I served my first Xmas dinner the year I was married 1906. On the Homestead at Nealsdale, Sask (near Watson) Just my Husband and I. My Mother in Law sent us a hamper from Winnipeg, Turkey, Plum Pudding candies, nuts etc.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No, never! We always had plenty to eat, when I was a kid at home in Manitoba, and after I married and lived on the Homestead for 3 years. Mostly just plain food, lots of it, and mostly raised on the farm. We hadn't money to buy fancy things. We had exactly $10.00 in cash when we started on the Homestead. My husband and I made hay (prairie wool) all summer 1906 and that fall many settlers came in and needed feed to winter their stock we sold about 100 loads at $2.00 a load. We were well away.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Describe any changes which you recall in the wrapping and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Most food was in bulk, and was put into paper bags and if necessary wrapped therein strong brown wrapping paper and tied with parcel string. The fancy containers and cans started to come in about 1910.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, a.m., winter or summer.

Born in Manitoba 1886 my early life spent 50 miles north east of Winnipeg in ranching country. As I remember breakfast did not vary much. Porridge, fried potatoes, meat, Bread & Butter MILK, Tea, or Coffee. Dinner beef, pork, fish or wild game, rice or tapioca pudding, Bread & Butter, Vegetable Syrup, Milk, Tea, Coffee. Supper, Bread & butter, Syrup, Jam sometimes a cake, not often. Plain wholesome food and lots of it. This was so in the 30s and 40s. Dad and Mother and seven kids.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

I ate my first Xmas dinner in Manitoba and if I remember right we had either Beef, Turkey, Chicken, Plum pudding and all the trimmings. My dad and Mother and one sister. I served my first Xmas dinner the year I was married 1906. On the Homestead at Neidale, Sask (near Watson) Just my Husband and I. My Mother-in-Law sent us a hamper from Winnipeg. Turkey, Plum Pudding, Candies, nuts etc.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No, never. We always had plenty to eat when I was a kid at home in Manitoba, and after I married and lived on the Homestead for 3 years. Mostly just plain food, lots of it, and mostly raised on the farm. We hadn't money to buy fancy things. We had exactly $10.00 in cash when we started on the Homestead. My husband and I made hay (prairie wool) all summer 1906 and that fall many settlers came in and needed feed to winter their stock. We sold about 100 lbs of at $2.00 a load. We were well away.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today. My early years were spent on ranch and farm, and of course the cooking was plain and wholesome (no hundred and one kinds of canned goods, which of course are handy today to cook up a meal quickly, canned soup, canned meat or fish, minute puddings, etc.). Breakfast is so different today. Fruit Juice, (can) Bran Flakes, etc., Toast coffee. The old days Porridge, (Oatmeal, not rolled oats, took at least half an hour to cook.) Then meat, maybe cold, or ham and eggs (both raised on farm), and fried potatoes, also raised on farm, coffee, tea or milk. Dinner, again a substantial meal, Roast or fried Beef, Pork, Fish, Puddings in those days, not so many pies as today, and always the syrup Jug, morning, Noon and night. Home made bread (today probably 50% of farmers buy bakers bread). Meat of some kind again for supper (imagine people anywhere having meat 3 times a day now). Better Now? Some things yes, others no.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible). About 1910, but of course the quantity of canned and prepared foods have increased over the years from that time until today, and the change has been gradual from home grown and home prepared foods, to the purchased and prepared foods; I still bake my own bread, we like it better than bakers. I still bake my own pies and cakes, and can some fruit. But gradually we fall in line with the big majority, and there is a larger pile of cans to be moved from the back yard every month end.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed). Actually people did not buy much in the way of "store" food in the old Homestead days: Main list for the store on the five or six times a year trip to town was flour, tea or Coffee, sugar, syrup, salt and Coal oil. Most people were trying to get "a start" and hadn't much money to spend on luxuries. The main diet was meat and vegetables raised on the farm, supplemented by game, deer & rabbits in winter and ducks, chickens, prairie & Gesees in summer & fall. I think perhaps the quality of goods were better on the whole in the early days, particularly clothing and boots, and of course the price of these were much lower than today. One could buy a good suit of clothes for $15.00, pair overalls 75¢ to $1.25. Fair work boots $1.75 and a new coat $5.00 for a pair of "best" shoes, it was the height of extravagance. Quality of foods and groceries were about the same as today but much cheaper. Coffee 18 to 20¢ today $1.00. Sugar 5¢/lb today 13¢. Display of goods is quite a feature today, shelf, window, and showcase. Service is a feature today also, you're no sooner in the store and a salesman or lady instantly appears with the question "may I help you"? There was none of this 50 years ago. The problem of storage was not great, we had (just my husband and I) a one room shack, a hole in the ground, and a trap door was the cellar where vegetables were stored. All else was stored in the one room, bed room, kitchen, dining, sitting, reception and bath room (12x16) 2 or 3 100 sacks of flour and a 100 sack sugar in one corner; coffee, rice, beans etc on a rough board shelf or cupboard in square tin boxes which would hold about 10 lbs. and were...
were safe from the mice, other small articles and dishes were on this shelf or cupboard (we had no china cabinet). The 5 gallon conical can stood in a corner. On yes the table was a large packing box in which had been stored between two chairs and a double bed and that was it. So you see there was really no storage problem to speak of. As regards shortages there just didn't seem to be any. We had lots of good plain food, lots of appetite, lots of hard work, lots of sunshine and lots of happiness, and lots of time to live. That was the slow age.
